prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Field 1 CO survey of 30 Doradus region
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We are mapping the 30 Doradus region (a.k.a. Tarantula Nebula) that has been recently mapped in the Hubble Tarantula Treasury Program (HTTP). The region is very large and is being mapped in several science goals, all of which are less than 150 pointings each.
It is possible to observe the transitions of CO and 13CO (in the J=2-1 transition) simultaneously with ALMA in opposite sidebands, in Band 6. The C18O (J=2-1) line can also be observed in conjunction with these. Using the narrowest bandwidth (~59 MHz), this configuration is accessible for targets with recession velocities <~2000 km/s (z~0.007). Our target is 274 km/s so within the range that allows this configuration.
Spectral averaging is used to decrease the data rate.
The required observing time is computed using 13CO (typically weaker than 12CO) as the representative frequency, which will help ensure detections at both 12CO and 13CO (but not necessarily C18O). The H-alpha 30 line and SiO lines are included to probe the ionized embedded massive stars and the shocked gas.
These mosaic observations require the ACA (7m + TP) because of the large angular extent of the target.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our correlator setup include three isotopes of CO: 12CO, 13CO and C18O that will be used to map the molecular gas distribution. We include two basebands that cover a broad bandwidth to measure continuum and to measure the H(30)alpha recombination line from embedded ionizing YSOs and SiO emission from YSO outflow shocks.
For the CO lines we adopt spectral resolutions of 0.092 for 12CO and 0.194 km/s for 13CO and C180. The spectral resolution of <0.2 km/s provides very good spectral sampling of these CO lines. The molecular gas will have a core line width of 1-5 km/s, but there may be some outflows around the YSOs that will add a broader component of 10 to 50 km/s. We need to sample the continuum around the line so need a spectral window width >150 km/s.
We adopt the full band width for Baseband-2 and Baseband-4 to increase a sensitivity of continuum observations. H(30) alpha and SiO have larger linewidths (20 km/s), so that the velocity resolution (1.5 to 2.5 km/s) can be coarser.

We need the 1 arcsec angular resolution to compare with the angular size of the YSO candidates (~2 arcsec) and the PMS maps which are 0.1 arcsec but will need to be binned to 1 arcsec for a star formation map. The largest angular scale is comparable to the size scales of the expected filaments and extended emission in the molecular gas in the region.. We request the ACA because we expect there will be extended 12CO emission in the region.

We set our sensitivity to measure the coolest molecular clouds expected, ~5 K. We expect the CO line widths to be 1-5 km/s. In our 1 arcsec beam, we set the sensitivty to 0.9K in a bandwidth of 0.2 km/s which is a reasonable sample of the linewidth that will resolve the line for the faintest molecular clouds in our survey.

Our target is 274 km/s so within the range that allows this configuration.
Spectral averaging is used to decrease the data rate.
The required observing time is computed using 13CO (typically weaker than 12CO) as the representative frequency, which will help ensure detections at both 12CO and 13CO (but not necessarily C18O). The H-alpha 30 line and SiO lines are included to probe the ionized embedded massive stars and the shocked gas.
These mosaic observations require the ACA (7m + TP) because of the large angular extent of the target.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our correlator setup include three isotopes of CO: 12CO, 13CO and C18O that will be used to map the molecular gas distribution. We include two basebands that cover a broad bandwidth to measure continuum and to measure the H(30)alpha recombination line from embedded ionizing YSOs and SiO emission from YSO outflow shocks.
For the CO lines we adopt spectral resolutions of 0.092 for 12CO and 0.194 km/s for 13CO and C180. The spectral resolution of <0.2 km/s provides very good spectral sampling of these CO lines. The molecular gas will have a core line width of 1-5 km/s, but there may be some outflows around the YSOs that will add a broader component of 10 to 50 km/s. We need to sample the continuum around the line so need a spectral window width >150 km/s.
We adopt the full band width for Baseband-2 and Baseband-4 to increase a sensitivity of continuum observations. H(30) alpha and SiO have larger linewidths (20 km/s), so that the velocity resolution (1.5 to 2.5 km/s) can be coarser.

We need the 1 arcsec angular resolution to compare with the angular size of the YSO candidates (~2 arcsec) and the PMS maps which are 0.1 arcsec but will need to be binned to 1 arcsec for a star formation map. The largest angular scale is comparable to the size scales of the expected filaments and extended emission in the molecular gas in the region.. We request the ACA because we expect there will be extended 12CO emission in the region.

We set our sensitivity to measure the coolest molecular clouds expected, ~5 K. We expect the CO line widths to be 1-5 km/s. In our 1 arcsec beam, we set the sensitivty to 0.9K in a bandwidth of 0.2 km/s which is a reasonable sample of the linewidth that will resolve the line for the faintest molecular clouds in our survey.

It is possible to observe the transitions of CO and 13CO (in the J=2-1 transition) simultaneously with ALMA in opposite sidebands, in Band 6. The C18O (J=2-1) line can also be observed in conjunction with these. Using the narrowest bandwidth (~59 MHz), this configuration is accessible for targets with recession velocities <~2000 km/s (z~0.007). Our target is 274 km/s so within the range that allows this configuration.
Spectral averaging is used to decrease the data rate.
The required observing time is computed using 13CO (typically weaker than 12CO) as the representative frequency, which will help ensure detections at both 12CO and 13CO (but not necessarily C18O). The H-alpha 30 line and SiO lines are included to probe the ionized embedded massive stars and the shocked gas.
These mosaic observations require the ACA (7m + TP) because of the large angular extent of the target.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a molecular gas survey of the 30 Doradus region to address two key topics in star formation. Is there an ISM gas threshold for star formation in the 30 Doradus region and how does it compare to values measured in the Galaxy? Does star formation occur in CO-dark molecular gas regions? Our survey covers the region imaged in the Hubble Tarantula Treasury Program (HTTP) that has discovered >16,700 pre-main sequence stars and will map the dust extinction at subarcsecond resolution. The HTTP pre-main sequence (PMS) stars and the young stellar objects (YSOs) from our Spitzer and Herschel studies provide a ~1 arcsecond map of the star formation activity. With ALMA, we will map the molecular gas with the 12CO J=2-1, 13CO J=2-1 and C18O J=2-1 lines at a comparable angular resolution of ~1 arc second. The H(30) alpha and SiO lines and continuum will constrain the nature of the ionization and shocks of the YSOs. The number counts of YSOs/PMS stars associated with the clump masses will determine the ISM gas threshold for star formation. Spatial comparison of the dust extinction image of HTTP with the CO map will delineate regions of CO-dark molecular gas.
